pattern: Subject + Verb + 得 + 倒 + Adjective

blocks.html: Indicating A Rebuking Tone with 倒
blocks.text: Indicating A Rebuking Tone with 倒

blocks.html: When using 倒 this way, link it together with a 得.When using this, usually the speaker has a rebuking tone. It's like saying "what you're saying is the opposite." In other words, something is not as said.
This grammar pattern is most commonly used with  说, sometimes with 想. 主语限于“你、你们、他、他们”等第二或者第三人称。多用于责备他人。

blocks.text: Subj. + Verb + 得 + 倒 + Adj.

children.english: It's easy for you to just say it. You should give it a try!
You must be talking when you sleep. You want to get paid without doing your job?
What you thought is too simple! How could that be possible?

blocks.html: Giving An Emphasis with 倒
Used in An Affirmative Sentence
倒 is mostly used with adjectives in this case to indicate the speaker is a little surprised.

children.english: This little girl is quite brave.
You're pretty good at talking.

blocks.html: A useful little phrase to admit concession is 那倒也是, something like "I guess so, I hadn't thought of it like that before." Or if on the contrary you are unwilling to concede, the phrases below can be used:
Used in A Negative Sentence
It's mostly used in these two pattens below:

• ⋯⋯ ，我 倒 不 觉得 。
  • ⋯⋯ ，我 倒 不 这么 + 看 / 想 / 认为 。

children.english: You all said this dish is spicy, but I disagree.
A lot of people think that he married her because of her money, but I don't think so.
A lot of people think that money is the most important, but I don't think so.

blocks.html: Using 倒是 in An Imperative Sentence

blocks.html: This pattern is used to urge somebody to response quickly.

blocks.text: 你 + 倒是 + Verb + 呀 / 啊

children.english: Please say something!
Please tell me!
Walk with me, please!
Please sign it! (Why are you hesitating?)

很是 is a degree adverb that adds emphasis to a sentence. It is more often used for literature than in spoken language.
很是 usually modifies two-syllable or multi-syllable adjectives,  but can also modify a small number of psychological verbs.

children.english: Doing it this way is very necessary.
Your performance at work has made the leader very satisfied.
When you wear a suit, you look very smart.
This matter made me very uncomfortable.
My boss really likes your design style.
He's already retired, but he's still starting a business. This makes me really admire him.
Your performance was too exaggerated, I really couldn't stand it.

blocks.text: Subj. + 很是 + 会 / 能 + Verb

blocks.html: Note that this usage is limited.

children.english: My dad was once a chef, he can really eat.
Although my sister is small, she can really talk a lot.
This man is very good at lying to women .
This boss can really drink.

Sometimes in English, we may want to emphasize how big, small, long, etc. something is perceived to be. We have all heard expressions like "he was a full 300 pounds," or "he was all of seven feet tall." The "a full" and "all of" in these sentences have an equivalent expression in Chinese: 足足 (zúzú).
You can put 足足 either in front or after the verb. Remember that 足足 adds emphasis to what you are saying, so you should always use it with a number. Some more commonly used verbs are 有 and 等.

向来 (xiànglái) is pretty much the same as 从来, except that 从来 is almost always used with negation (sentences with 不 or 没）.

向来 is used the same structure as 从来.You can use an optional 都 after the 向来.The basic meaning of 向来 is that something is always like that until the present. 一向 has the same meaning and structure as 向来。

children.english: My parents have always disliked me going out to play with you guys.
I have always pushed myself, so every time I take a test, I always get full marks.
That soccer player is known as "Goldfoot" because he plays soccer really well.

You can add the adverb 果然 (guǒrán) to add the sense that what you're about to say is entirely expected. It's kind of like starting a sentence with "just as we thought" or "just as we expected," but it's just one word in Chinese. It's kind of like the opposite of 竟然 or 居然.

children.english: She won the first prize! I knew it.
The food that the chef cooked is extraordinary! Delicious!
You were right. He's absolutely a liar!
This painkiller works really well. My headache is gone.

blocks.html: Used as before a Clause
果然 can also come before a full independent clause. In this case, it is usually preceded by a comma.

children.english: The taxi driver said he would be here very soon. His car got here in only two minutes.
He told me not to worry about it. He fixed out internet very soon.
It rained heavily this morning as the weather forecast said.
He is the mole, as I expected.

children.english: It seems that she's only in her early thirties while she's already about fifty.

title: Expressing "as long as" with "fanshi"
pattern: 凡是 + Noun 都 / 就 / 一律 + Predicate

blocks.html: 凡是(fánshì)，副词，指在某个范围内的所有事物或情况，没有例外，意思是"只要是"。用于句子的开头，用来修饰名词或名词性词组，口语中常和"就、都、一律"等搭配使用。

blocks.text: 凡是 + Noun + 都 / 就 / 一律 + Predicate

children.english: As long as the food is made of egg, he wouldn't like.
As long as the kid doesn't behave well, he won't get any candy to eat.
As long as you have a membership, you can benefit from a discount.
As long as you're an American citizen, you can vote. Is this true?
As long as you sign up three days in advance, you can enter free of charge.
As long as you haven't take an physical examination, you can't donate blood.
As long as you kill someone, you will be sentenced to death. Is that true?

blocks.html: 凡是 can also be used with 无不 and 均. 无不 literally means 没有一个不, which gives a stronger tone of emphasis. 均 simply means 都 in written language.
凡 is used more in written language than 凡是.

blocks.text: 凡(是) + Noun + 无不 / 均 + Predicate

children.english: Everyone is surprised as long as they've heard about this.
Everyone are amazed by his acting skills as long as they've seen his acting.
The product must be returned as long as it's not qualified.
As long as the athletes take stimulants, they will be punished very seriously.

偏偏 (piānpiān) is probably one of the hardest adverbs for Chinese learners to master, since it is actually quite nuanced in the ways that it is used. Usually it begins the second clause of a sentence, and it expresses that something contrary to expectations has happened. There are two types of expectations: objective requirements and hopes/desires.
In addition, 偏偏 can also express a meaning similar to 仅仅 or 只有, with an air of dissatisfaction.
The structure is pretty simple. First, a statement is said in the first clause to "set up" the situation (A), then 偏偏 is placed before or after the subject in the second clause (B).
All of these examples are similar, but they have some small key differences.

In these example sentences, we see that the opposite of what is expected comes out. In this case "what is expected" is a objective requirement. We see that when you don't call him to go, he does what is unexpected and wants to go. Basically, 偏偏 here expresses that someone or something has an idea/thought/action that is the opposite to what everyone thinks.

In these three example sentences, we see that the opposite what one hopes or desires has happened. In the first sentence, we see that the person is expected to come visit, but on the one day he comes that person is not home. Basically, the person's hope and reality do not match up.

In this last set of three example sentences, we see that 偏偏 has a meaning similar to 仅仅 or 只有. It also has an air of dissatisfaction. For example, in the second sentence, everyone is early, expect for that one person who is late. Using 偏偏 here is a way to complain about the situation.

无非 (wúfēi) means "only," or "nothing but." People use 无非 to soften the meaning of what they're talking about, or to stress that what they're saying isn't serious or awesome. The end of the sentence sometimes has 罢了 or 而已.
Adding a 是 is optional. Using 是 is more colloquial.
The use of "是" here is not optional.

To express something is unexpected, you can use the adverb 竟然 (jìngrán) after the subject. 竟然 has the same meaning as 居然, but is not as intense.
Like many other adverbs, 竟然 is placed after the subject. This grammar structure is usually used in spoken Chinese.
You can also drop out the 然 and use just 竟. This can be used in spoken or written Chinese.
Note that it can be difficult to translate the word 竟然 into an appropriate English word. Sometimes it's just a feeling that doesn't come across well in English unless you can hear the tone of voice.

children.english: I didn't expect you could lie in front of the teacher's face.
This is something that makes people sad, but you are actually laughing?
He is so hardworking, but, surprisingly, he didn't pass the exam.
You got ripped off by that guy.
Everyone thought he would say no,  but he said yes.
This project is so complex, but it's been completed so soon.

到时候(dào shíhou) basically means the same thing as "when the times comes." Usually "when the time comes" is pointing to a specific event in the future.
General use of "到时候"
Usually this grammar pattern starts with a statement to set things us (A), then the things that happens in the future is stated (B) after the 到时候.

children.english: If you don't prepare well, then you won't do it well in the exam.
I want to learn the Chinese song "Happy Birthday." I'll sing for you guys when the time comes.
You can give it a try first. I will teach you when the time comes.

blocks.html: Commonly used expressions with 到时候
blocks.text: Commonly used expressions with 到时候

children.english: See you then.
Let's see what we can do later.
We will talk about that later when the time comes.

副词，用于反问，"为什么一定要⋯⋯"的意思，表示"不必"，语气"不必"重。多用于后一分句。
In this case, 何必 is often used to indicate the speaker's attitude about something unnecessary or not worth doing.
口语中，谓语可省略主要动词，"何必"直接加名词性成分。如：

children.english: Why next week?(Why wait?) I have time this week.
Why the general manager? The manager can totally be our representative.

blocks.html: 何必 can be used alone with 呢 together to mean "why?"

children.english: You bought us gifts again? Why?

来着 is an auxiliary word placed at the end of a sentence to express that something has already happened.
General use of "来着" in the sentence
blocks.text: General use of "来着" in the sentence

blocks.html: 来着 is placed at the end of the sentence. 来着 does not have a negative form, in other words, it cannot be used with 不 or 没(有). Also, when 来着 is used in a question, it can only be used with 什么, 谁, and 哪儿.

children.english: There was someone looking for you yesterday.
That book was here yesterday. Why can't I find it today?
What was his name again?
Who sang that song again?
Where is it that we said we are going to this weekend?

blocks.html: Special phrase "I told you so" with 来着
blocks.text: Special phrase  "I told you so" with 来着

blocks.html: 来着 is used in a common expression similar to "didn't I tell you!?," used when the speaker wants to prove that they are right about something. The phrase is "我说什么来着."

children.english: I told you so! You have a diarrhea every time you eat hotpot!
I told you so! This thing must be fake!
I told you so! He is not really into you!
I told you so! They would come back.

则 is a conjunction that helps us to indicate contrast.

This grammar pattern takes two things and makes a comparison. The second clause of the sentence (which includes the 则) describes another thing with a contrasting characteristic. In this instance, 则 has the same meaning as 却.
You can also use this structure with 而, and it will have the same meaning.

In written Chinese, many phrases are shortened or simplified. In this article, we will look at how 以免 is used, which can be considered the shortened form of 以便避免, meaning "in order to avoid."

In this grammar structure, the first clause brings up a reminder or a warning, and then the second clause starts of with 以免 (in order to) and tells the consequence of what happens if  the reminder or warning is ignored.
Make sure that 以免 is not used with a single verb or adjective. It must be used with a complete verb phrase.
以免 can also be used with a sentence after it, with its own subject and predicate.

In formal written Chinese, 本 can mean "this side," as in "this company" or "this country." It always refers to the side that the speaker is on.

本(běn) can means a few different types of "this." It can refer to oneself, a place, an organization, or even a certain time. The noun that's used with 本 is very often single-syllable noun, like 人, 校, 市, 省, 国, 周, 月, 年, 次, etc. 公司, 组织, 季度, 学期 are also commonly used with 本.
Notice that the last example is 本人. It expresses "this person," which is like a fancy way of saying 我. This is especially common is resumes and cover letters.

性 can be added after a word to express a characteristic or property. This is the equivalent of adding a "-ility" or "-ness" to English words, such as turning "possible" to "possibility" or “hard" to "hardness." It is also the equivalent of adding "-ic" to words, such as turing "history" to "historic."

Since this is a suffix, it can be added to the end of words, similar to 化 Pay attention to the words that can be used with 性. While there is no set rule on what can or cannot be used, there are trends we can look at.

In advanced, colloquial Chinese, you may hear 呗 at the end of sentences. This particle is similar to 吧 and expresses "it's just this way." It points out something that is obvious.
Use 呗 the same way you would any other particle, like 吧. Put it at the end of your sentence.

呗 is one of those nuanced particles that has a few possible explanations. It can indicate that something is obvious, or it can express resignation. It can also express a lack of enthusiasm, or that something should or can only be done a certain way.

鉴于 (jiànyú) is a preposition that expresses that a certain situation has gone through previous thought and consideration. 鉴于 can be thought of as "in light of," "in view of," "seeing that," etc.
鉴于 is used the same way as "in regards to." Just put it in the beginning of your sentence. This grammar structure is used in written or formal contexts.

title: Adding emphasis with "fei....buke"
pattern: Subj. + 非(要) + Verb Phrase (+ 不可)

blocks.html: Most advanced Chinese learners know how to express "wanting to do something" with 要, but sometimes you need to turn it up a degree and express "absolutely insist on doing something." In that case, you can use 一定要 or 非要. Most time 非要 appears with a self-willed emotional color while一定要 is just a expression of "absolutely wanting " or "absolutely insist" without any emotional color.
When used before a verb, 非⋯⋯ 不可 expresses that the speaker has strong desire and determination to do that thing.

blocks.text: Subj. + 非(要) + [Verb Phrase] + 不可

blocks.html: 不可 is often omitted when the speaker dislike the action or disagree on the action.

children.english: It's so cold today, but my daughter is determined to wear skirt.
I don't want him to drink so much, but he had to.
I didn't want to go, but she made me go.
My girlfriend made me give her roses on Valentine's Day.

blocks.html: It can be also used to emphasize something must be done or must be someone. Actually it has the similar meaning with 必须 in this case.
Note that 要 is not necessary in this pattern.
In that case, you can use 一定会 instead.

blocks.text: 非(要) + Subj. + [Verb Phrase] + 不可

blocks.html: Note 不可 can't be omitted in this sentence pattern.

Just insert 岂不是 where you feel that "could it be that" or "isnt it." 岂不是 is usually used to start a new sentence or a clause. Since it is a rhetorical question, the speaker already knows the answer.

兼（jiān）can be used to express doing two or more different jobs or identities.

Usually this grammar structure is used to express two (or more) simultaneous jobs or identities. It's kind of like saying "I'm a student. At the same time, I'm a programmer." The structure itself is pretty simple, you can put the 兼 after or before the verb.

title: Expressing “must" with "feidei"
pattern: 非得 + Action + 不可/不行/不成

blocks.html: 非得 (fēiděi) can be translated as "must" or "have to." Usually it appears in the grammar structure 非得...不可/不行/不成, which expresses something is supposed to be a certain way and not change, or that something will certainly happen.
Many of you are probably familiar with the grammar structure 非...不可, which is the simplified form of this structure.
In this grammar structure, we are saying that the action must be done. Usually there is a phrase to set up the context, and then what must be done.

blocks.text: Statement,  非 (得) + Action + 不可 / 不行

莫过于 can be easily understood as "cannot surpass." It is usually used in literary and formal Chinese to give emphasis to something, emphases that something is the "best" .  It is similar to how in English we might say "Nothing is more delicious, not even the world's best restaurants, than my mother's cooking."

In this structure, you first state the topic or a question and then give your answer that you think the best. The answer comes after the 莫过于. 莫过于 is one of the phrases that comes from 文言文 Chinese. The 莫 means "not" or "nobody," and the 过于 means "surpass."

blocks.text: Topics or questions + 莫过于 + answer

children.english: For America's best college, nothing is better than Harvard.
Nothing is sadder in life than losing a loved one.
Nothing makes her sadder than you shouting at her.
The most romantic thing I can imagine is getting old together with you.
To parents, nothing is more comforting than their kids being able to lead independent lives.

title: Expressing "rather than..." with "yuqi... buru"
pattern: 与其 + A，宁可 / 宁愿 / 宁肯）+ B

blocks.html: Just like any other language, Chinese has many ways of expressing preference. One of the common ways is to use the 与其...不如（yǔqí...bùrú), and other similar variations.
Using 与其 with 不如
blocks.text: Using 与其 with 不如

blocks.html: When a speaker uses 与其...不如（yǔqí...bùrú) to express "Prefer...rather than," he is choosing B over A. Both options could be good in some way. Or to the speaker, B is obviously much better than A. It usually gives a strong emphasis on the speaker's attitude or opinion. You can also add 还, 倒, 真 before the 不如.

children.english: The weather is so nice. We'd rather go out for a walk than stay at home and watch TV.
I'd rather find something to do than just wait like this.
I'd rather ask him face to face than think recklessly.
I'd rather to work for myself than work for other people.
Instead of troubling other people, I'd rather think of the solution.

blocks.html: Using 与其 with 宁

与其...宁可(yǔqí...nìngkě) expresses preference by making a comparison. In this grammar pattern, both options are bad. But the first option (A) is rejected, and the second option (B) is taken. This is like saying "in comparison to A, I would rather B." You can also swap out the 宁愿(nìngyuàn) or 宁肯(nìngkěn) , which have the same meaning. In spoken Chinese, this patter is less used than 宁可.

blocks.text: 与其 ⋯⋯ ，Subj. + 宁可 / 宁愿 ⋯⋯

children.english: I'd rather stay single than find a random one.
Instead of going, I‘d rather start to work first.
My grandfather would rather live in the old house in the countryside than stay in strange big city.
I'd rather break up with sooner him than keep hurting each other.
We'd rather to buy a big house in suburban area than buy a small one in the city area with the same amount of money.

blocks.html: Expressing an objective observation with 与其说
blocks.text: Expressing an objective observation with 与其说

blocks.html: In this structure, the speaker is basically saying the same thing, but actually using it with the verb 说. It expresses an objective judgment or evaluation, and according to the speaker, the latter part (B) is more correct or accurate than the earlier part (A).

blocks.text: 与其说 + A，不如说 + B

children.english: I'd rather say that he's my friend than my teacher.
I'd rather say that she's helping herself than she's helping you.
I'd rather say that he was playing than cook.
I'd rather say it's a action movie than a love movie.
I'd rather say that he was criticizing me than encouraging me.

"一来...二来..." is a grammar pattern that helps us organize thoughts. It helps us to state two or more reasons or goals.

This pattern is similar to the English "for one thing...., for another." You can start with a clause explaining the outcome, and then explaining the reasons with "一来...二来..." Make sure to keep in mind that these should be reasons, aims or purposes.Each clause should be separated by a comma.
The 是 and 也 are optional.

One of the most elegant grammar patterns is 以 A 为 B (yǐ A wéi B). It is often found in formal writing and speech, and it is also one of the classical Chinese forms that is still in use today. In short, it means "Using A as B" or "taking A as B."
This grammar pattern is as versatile as "using/taking A as B" is in English. We might say "take his example as our standard," "use this piece as an example," or "take charity as our central tenet."

In this article, we look at at a grammar at the grammar pattern 不屑. Normally, you may think of 屑 as having to do with bits of something, like 木屑, 铁屑 etc. It also means "to believe something is worth doing ." In that case, 不屑 means "to believe that something is not worth doing."
It is important to note that there is an element of disdain to 不屑, so the subject using 不屑 looks down on doing the action.
In this structure, you can say 不屑 or 不屑于. Both have the same meaning, though  不屑于 is a bit more literary.
以便 (yǐbiàn)  is a formal way to say "in order to" or "to facilitate," and is generally used to show that an outcome is the result of a particular action.

blocks.html: 何况 (hékuàng) can mean "let alone" or "all the more."
何况 within a rhetorical question
blocks.text: 何况 within a rhetorical question
Subj. + 连 ⋯⋯ 都 + Verb ，何况 ⋯⋯ 呢 ？

blocks.html: 呢 often appears at the end of this structure, to form a rhetorical question. 更 or 又 can be added to 何况 to add further emphasis.
何况 can be used in two ways, the first of which where 何况 is used to emphasize that if A is like this, then B must be even more so.

children.english: Children can understand what this sentence means, let alone the adults.
He can answer a question that hard, let alone answer one that easy.

blocks.html: In the above sentences, as A is so easy, then B must be even easier. However if one adds a 不 or 没 before the verb then the meaning is reversed: now A is so hard, B would almost be impossible.

blocks.text: Subj. + 连 ⋯⋯ 都 + 不 / 没 + Verb ，何况 ⋯⋯ 呢 ？

children.english: My grandmother hasn't even taken the high-speed train, let alone the airplane.
The baby can't even walk, let alone run.
I don't even know what his name is, let alone his phone number.

blocks.html: 何况 doesn't necessarily have to be used with the 连⋯⋯ 都⋯⋯ structure, and can be used as a simple statement instead of a rhetorical question.
何况 in a statement

blocks.text: Subj. (+ 尚且) + 都 / 就 ⋯⋯ ，（更）何况 ⋯⋯

children.english: He don't talk much at home, let alone on public occasion.
Two men can't move this this, let alone a single woman.
This place has always been hard to find, especially on your first time.
Adults can't even do this, let alone children.
Chinese people don't even know much about it, let alone foreigners.

blocks.html: 何况 is often used with 尚且, a formal way of saying 还. 更 can be added to 何况 to add further emphasis.

The differences between 不得不 (bùdébù) and 只好 (zhǐhǎo) are: 只好 means there is no better choice, 不得不 means there is no other choice.[1]
不得不 and 只好 use the same structure
blocks.text: 不得不 and 只好 use the same structure

blocks.html: They both indicate that there are no other choices available. In other words, something unwanted has to be done. They both use the same grammar pattern: just place either 不得不 or 只好 before the verb.
不得不 has a stronger tone than 只好. It is the same as 不得已 or 无可奈何, meaning "someone cannot help but do something."

In the first example above, the person has no other choice but to leave the the luggage at the friend's house. In the second example, the person decides that the best option is the leaving it at the friend's house. (perhaps it's a better option than renting a storage unit, leaving it at the airport etc.)
One other thing, 不得不 can only be followed by a positive phrase (meaning a phrase that does not contain 不 or 没), 只好 can be followed either by a positive or negative phrase (it can have a 不 or 没).
Commonly used expressions with 不得不
blocks.text: Commonly used expressions with 不得不

If something keeps happening and won't stop happening, we say that it is "continuous" or "incessant." In Chinese, the words are 不断 (bùduàn) and 不停 (bùtíng). These two words are usually adverbs in Chinese, but they can sometimes be adjectives too. Their uses are subtly different, so this article will help you distinguish when and where to use them.
"不断" is usually placed before the verb it modifies, and it often requires the particle "地" to show that it is an adverb.

children.english: The client won't stop changing his ideas. What should I do?
For two years, we continuously pushed ourselves and continuously improved.
The argument between them is ongoing. The relationship is consistently worsening.

blocks.html: "不停" is a little more versatile and can be placed both before the verb as an adverb, or after the verb as something that is somewhat like a complement. Either way, it means the same thing.

children.english: I'm so tired today. I can't stop yawning.
I got a cold. My throat hurts and my nose runs constantly.
When he's eating, he doesn't say anything. He doesn't stop eating.

blocks.html: When "不停" comes after the verb, it behaves somewhat strangely and takes "个" before it in order to become grammatical, like so:

children.english: The child is crying constantly. Does he have a fever?
You've been talking non-stop. It's too noisy.
The phone is ringing off the hook today. It's so annoying.
All day long, the wife doesn't stop nagging. Would you be able to stand it?

blocks.html: Learning how to properly use 反而 (fǎn'ér) and 却 (què) may seem like a head ache, but it isn't! This article will help you out!
They are placed in different parts of the sentence
blocks.text: They are placed in different parts of the sentence

blocks.html: 反而 can be placed before or after the subject. 却 can only be placed after the subject.
Structure for 反而

children.english: However you did it, the quality was no good.
However you did it, the quality was no good.

blocks.html: Structure for 却

children.english: It's raining outside, and I didn't bring an umbrella.

blocks.html: 反而 can point to any part of the sentence to make a turning point, and it often emphasizes the structure around 是. On the other hand, 却 can only make a turning point for the the whole sentence, in other words, it can only make a turning point for the predicate part of the sentence.
反而 can change any part of the sentence
blocks.text: 反而 can change any part of the sentence

children.english: The Chicago Bulls didn't win their last game, but the Knicks did.
They all thought the Knicks were going to lose the last game, but they won.
I thought the Knicks would win the first game, but they won the last one.

blocks.html: 却 only changes the whole sentence
blocks.text: 却 only changes the whole sentence

children.english: The Chicago Bulls didn't win their last game, but the Knicks did.
They all thought the Knicks would lose the last game, but they won.
I though the Knicks would win the first game, but they lost.

blocks.html: 反而 and 却 express different degrees
blocks.text: 反而 and 却 express different degrees

blocks.html: Sentences with 反而 express a strong and sudden turn, possibly exceeding expectations. Sentences with 却 are just common turning points. 反而 could be a 180°degree turn, while 却 could be just a 90°.

children.explanation: This is a normal turn of events.
children.english: I helped him, but he wasn't happy.

children.explanation: The speaker thought the other person would be happy.
children.english: I helped him, but he wasn't happy.

blocks.html: Both of these often appear in set structures, as seen below:
不但没⋯⋯，反而
不但不⋯⋯，反而
反而却/却反而

children.english: She likes to eat sweet things, but she doesn't eat chocolate.
She likes to eat sweet things, but she doesn't eat chocolate.

I used to bring them up a lot, but you didn't commend me for it. Instead you said I spoke too much, so now I don't speak.

The main differences between 根本 (gēnběn) and 到底 (dàodǐ) is that 根本 is used to emphasize negation and 到底 is used in a question to ask the result of something. 根本 can be used to emphasize a negative statement, 到底 cannot be used this way. 根本 is often used to emphasize sentences with 不 or 没(有). Using 根本 this way is a response to something stated beforehand. Using 到底 this way would be incorrect.
Use of 根本
根本 is used to emphasize negation.

children.english: I just don't know how to manage effectively.
Why did say you saw me on the street yesterday? I didn't even go out!
He's just a small kid. He hasn't ever seen such scary stuff.

blocks.html: Use of 到底

到底 is usually used with question words, 根本 is not。到底 implies some kind of inquiry, and actually it can be thought of as "on earth," as in "what on earth are you doing?" It always includes some kind of question word, such as 谁, 什么, 哪里, and so on, or it can even be used with yes-no questions.

children.english: The new co-worker came late again today. Does he want to work here or not?
Your bag is so heavy! How much stuff are you even carrying?
The meeting has already been going on for two hours. When on earth are we going to finish?

blocks.html: Examples of right and wrong sentences
blocks.text: Examples of right and wrong sentences

children.explanation: "到底" is normally used for questions.
"到底" is normally used for questions.
"根本" should be used with negations
"到底" is used to emphasize the speaker's impatience.
"根本" should be used to emphasize the negation, not the question.

The main differences between 根据 (gēn jù) and 据 (jù) are in how 据 is specifically used.
Basically, 据 can be used with single character words, while 根据 has to use words with at least two characters or more.

children.english: according to facts
according to facts
according to facts

blocks.html: Pairings with 据
据 can be used with together with 说, 闻, 悉, 传, 根据 cannot. These set two-character phrases are often used in formal and written Chinese, especially in news reports.

children.english: They say he's gone to Shanghai.
They say he's gone to Shanghai.
It is rumored that the Prime Minister is going to resign.
It is rumored that the Prime Minister is going to resign.

blocks.html: Referring to people using 据

据 is often used when referring to people. Often it is used with "某人说" or "某人看来," just substitute that 某人 with the person you are referring to (or you can also refer to yourself). If you use 根据, you need to use that person's name along with a noun phrase.

children.english: According to him, the disaster was not very serious.
According to him, the disaster was not very serious.
In my opinion, he is a very responsible person.
In my opinion, he is a very responsible person.

This may be one of the trickiest two verbs to get right. 恢复 means to restore something that was destroyed and 还原 means returning something to its original state.
Meaning and usage of 恢复
blocks.text: Meaning and usage of 恢复

blocks.html: 恢复 expressing that something is restored that was once destroyed, messed up, or lost. It comes back into its original state or appearance. Often it is used with words like 身体, 体力, 社会, 秩序 etc.
One way to use 恢复 is to put it before the noun or noun phrase
Using 恢复 at the end of a sentence
blocks.text: Using 恢复 at the end of a sentence

blocks.html: You can also put 恢复 after, usually paired with a 了.
"Restoring to original condition" with 还原
blocks.text: "Restoring to original condition" with 还原

blocks.html: 还原 also means "returning to the original state or condition," but this time it is strongly emphasizing going back exactly to how it was before. It does not have the same "destroyed" connotation of 恢复.
Grammar pattern-wise, it's pretty much used the same way as 恢复.

居然 (jūrán) and 反而 (fǎn‘ér) both indicate that something is unexpected, or beyond common expectations.
Both 居然 and 反而 are used in similar structures
blocks.text: Both 居然 and 反而 are used in similar structures

blocks.html: The following two grammar structures show us that 反而 and 居然 can be used in the same grammar pattern.

blocks.text: Clause 1, 反而 / 居然 + unexpected opposite outcome

blocks.html: 反而 can also be used in some specific grammar patterns
blocks.text: 反而 can also be used in some specific grammar patterns

blocks.html: However, 反而 is often used with 不仅没有 (不但没有) or 不仅不 (不但不). You cannot use 居然 here. This pattern basically means "but not only...on the contrary..."

blocks.text: Clause 1, 不仅没有（不但没有）/ 不仅不 (不但不)......反而......

blocks.html: 居然 is for unexpected things, 反而 is more of a turning point
blocks.text: 居然 is for unexpected things, 反而 is more of a turning point

blocks.html: 反而 is used to express "on the contrary" or "in contrast," and it is usually placed in the second part of the sentence. Note that the meaning of 反而 goes beyond just "but." It is used to explain that something is totally the opposite of what one was expecting.
居然 is not as intense as 反而. What's more, 居然 not only brings up an unexpected thing, it also allows the speaker to give a comment on that unexpected thing.
In these examples "太不像话了," "真是了不起," "真是太不可思议了," and "真是缘分呐" are the comments.

一时(yī shí) and 一度(yī dù) both look like they have the same meaning, and the way they are used structurally is the same, but in actuality they are pretty different.
一度 can mean "only once"
When 一度 means "once," it is used in a set phrase, like "一年一度."
当一度表示一次时，一般有个固定用法“一年一度”。
一度 can also mean a time period that has passed
blocks.text: 一度 can also mean a time period that has passed

blocks.html: 一度 can also express diong something in a period of time that has passed. It is often a bad thing, and it often is placed with a verb or verb phrase.
表示过去一段时间一直做了某件事，大多数是不好的事情。常常后面接动词或动词短语
一时 can mean "a short while"
blocks.text: 一时 can mean "a short while"

blocks.html: 一时 can express doing something in a period of time whether it has passed or not.
一时 can also mean "sometimes, temporary or suddenly"
blocks.text: 一时 can also mean "sometimes, temporary or suddenly"

Both 一直 (yīzhí) and 一向 (yīxiàng) mean something close to "all along," and deal with continuous actions. However, their uses are subtly different, and they are a pair of words that are often confused (and tested on!).

一直 means "straight" or "constantly" and it has the sense of doing something continuously "since a certain time." This means that something may have occurred, and then 一直 can be used with the action or habit since that point. It's important to note that this point in time doesn't necessarily have to be in the past, so 一直 can be used to say something "will happen repeatedly" in the future.

children.english: I will always be with you.
It's constantly raining, I have no way to go out.
Keep walking ahead, you will see the subway station on your right.
He kept talking while I was reading. It was annoying.
He hasn't found a job that he really enjoys ever since graduating from college.

blocks.html: 一向 does not have a starting point in time specified like 一直 does. Instead, it means that things have always been like they are. In this way, it is more like a habit. Furthermore, it is often used to express a habit or event that you don't like, and can also be used in conjunction with 不.

children.english: He never comes late. How is it that he hasn't come yet today?
You know mom has never liked going out, so she is not going to go on the trip with us.
She has always liked showing off. She's horrible.
This friend of mine has always been very generous, so today he's definitely paying.
I have never cared about such things.

blocks.html: However, 一向 also can’t affect words that indicate some change (as this wouldn’t be a habit), nor can it talk about constant future actions. For both of these cases, 一直 should be used instead.

  • "Since the beginning" with "yixiang"

彼此 (bǐcǐ) and 对方 (duìfāng) are both personal pronouns, and both can sometimes be translated as "each other" in English. 对方 (duìfāng), however, points to the "opposite" or "other" side. 彼此 (bǐcǐ), however, stresses "between" or "among each other".
彼此 (bǐcǐ) can be used after personal pronouns like 你们, 我们, and 大家. 对方 (duìfāng) cannot be used in this way.
Before a verb, you can use 彼此 to mean "each other," but not 对方. This is similar to using 互相 (hùxiàng) before a verb.

children.english: You both did this to hurt each other.
Before they get married, the bride and groom should spend more time getting to know each other.
We are from the same department. We should cooperate with each other in our work.
If you can't trust each other, this partnership probably won't succeed.

blocks.html: Both can be used as an object after a verb. The verbs are usually two-syllable ones. 对方 usually refers to "the other side," except when addressing multiple people at once. When addressing several people, 对方 is often translated into English as "each other." 彼此 feels a bit literary in style than 对方.

children.english: They can take care of each other, you don't have to worry.
You two should forgive each other.
Do you think we can trust each other?
Lili and Xiao Ming did not respect each other at all, so they fought a lot.

blocks.html: Both can be placed before a noun, as attributive modifiers. Again, 对方 normally refers to "the other side's," but when addressing several people, 对方 is often translated into English as "each other's."

blocks.text: 彼此 / 对方 + 的 + Noun

children.english: You should both pay more attention to each other's strengths.
They both hate each other's relatives.
He often ignores others' feelings when he talks to people.

blocks.html: 对方 used as "the other side"
blocks.text: 对方 used as "the other side"

blocks.html: 对方 can also mean "the other side," whereas 彼此 cannot. This one is straightforward.

children.english: I apologized to him, but he didn't accept it.
I asked, but they didn't agree.
Talking like that is going to make them very uncomfortable.
When we have an argument with a friend, we all hope the other side will apologize first.

blocks.html: 反而 (fǎn'ér) is an adverb, while 相反 (xiāngfǎn) is an adjective and also a conjunction, and this determines how they are used grammatically.
相反 normally starts a sentence, and when used should be followed with a comma. As an adverb, 反而 is not so set apart from the rest of the sentence, and should not be followed by a comma.

children.english: This won't help him. On the contrary, it will harm him.
Not only will this not help him, on the contrary it will harm him.

blocks.html: 反而 is used in the context of the speaker expecting some kind of turning point. 相反 is for similar things that have a different aspect.  反而 conveys that the difference between what was expected and what actually happened was quite large. 相反 isn't as strong.

blocks.text: Situation，相反，The Opposite of the Situation
Expectation，反而 + The Opposite of Expectation

children.english: If you work hard, you will be promoted. Contrarily, you will not be promoted if you don't work hard.
The boss isn't angry. On the contrary, he praised me.
The boss isn't angry. Actually, he praised me.

blocks.html: 相反 can act as an attribute
blocks.text: 相反 can act as an attribute

blocks.html: 相反 is an adjective, and of course it can also be an attribute. Just make sure to add a 的 after it. 反而 cannot be used this way.

children.english: These are two completely opposite results.
You should go down a different path.

blocks.html: 相反 can be the predicate
blocks.text: 相反 can be the predicate

blocks.html: 相反, like all other adjectives, can be placed after the subject as the predicate of the sentence.

blocks.text:
Subj. + 相反
A 和 / 跟 B ＋ 是 ＋ 相反的

children.english: These two art pieces have completely different forms.
Our perspectives are not the same.
The boss's way of thinking and mine don't match up.
The views of today are different from what they were in the past.
